Title:
A pluripotency-mediating POU domain transcription factor in
cnidarian stem cells
Keywords:
iPS cells; Cnidaria; interstitial cells; i-cells;
nematocyte; differentiation
Abstract:
Early mammalian embryos include pluripotent cells that
have the capacity to differentiate into any adult cell type. This
property is induced and maintained by a small number of key
transcription factors, of which the POU domain protein, Oct4, is
considered central. Clonal invertebrates, in contrast, possess
pluripotent stem cells life-long, but the molecular mechanisms
controlling their pluripotency is poorly studied. To address this
problem, we analyzed the expression pattern and function of Polynem
(Pln), a POU domain gene from the marine cnidarian Hydractinia echinata.
We show that Pln is expressed in the embryo and adult stem cells of the
animal. Its ectopic expression in epithelial cells induces stem cell
neoplasms and loss of epithelial tissue. Neoplasm cells expressed not
only endogenous Pln, but also Nanos, Vasa, Piwi and Myc. Pln
downregulation by retinoic acid or RNAi in adult animals lead to
differentiation. Downregulation of the gene in early embryogenesis was
lethal. Our results suggest an ancient role of POU proteins in animal
stem cells.
